abstract.text: Update your apps to use new features, and test your apps against API changes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The macOS 11.3 SDK provides support to develop apps for Macs running macOS Big Sur 11.3. The SDK comes bundled with Xcode 12.5, available from the Mac App Store. For information on the compatibility requirements for Xcode 12.5, see
Support for the Developer Transition Kit is no longer available as of macOS Big Sur 11.3.
Many SF Symbols now have default accessibility labels. (70305995)
Using
in a subclass of a type conforming to
now correctly publishes changes. (71816443)
Added
, a new style for

views that shows both the title and icon of the label using a system-standard layout. In most cases, labels show both title and icon by default. However, some containers might apply a different default label style to their content, such as only showing icons within toolbars on macOS and iOS. To opt in to showing both the title and the icon, apply the title and icon label style:
Types conforming to any style protocol, such as
or

, are now enforced to be value types. Styles must be structures or enumerations, not classes, and conforming a class to a style protocol may trigger an assertion. This is the same restriction that the system has always enforced on types conforming to
A custom
in an app built against an SDK prior to macOS 11.3 now appears correctly when run on macOS 11.3. (74721633)
Labels for some controls in a customizable toolbar now show as expected in Icon and Text display mode. (73911090)
The outline for a
now updates correctly when its data collection changes to or from an empty value. (71264665)
and

now reflect the first published value the system encounters in a leading-to-trailing traversal of the active window’s view hierarchy. This allows focused values published at the root of your view tree with
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/swiftui/tabview/focusedvalue(_:_:)-7a6lz
to be visible by default when there’s no focused view hierarchy from which the systems can read a more contextually-specific value. (59321659)
fonts are no longer overridden based on the
of the system environment for apps built with the macOS 11.3 SDK. (72098357)
Setting
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/swiftui/text/preferredcolorscheme(_:)
to
now correctly resets to the system’s preferred color scheme. (67000774)
apps now show an Open panel on launch, even when iCloud isn’t in use. (66446310)
controls in Optimized for Mac Catalyst apps now look and function as expected. (69932695)
Constraints on sheet content using a
modifier are no longer lost if the content had a
There’s no longer default spacing between sheet content and its associated
elements. Explicit padding should be added if required. (70146121)
background colors now resolve correctly in apps built with Mac Catalyst. (70751748)
A
now updates as expected when its
data changes between being flat or empty and having hierarchy. (71354760)
Dismissing a sheet no longer causes the window to close unexpectedly. (71541062)
Dynamic properties such as
, and others now work correctly in
instances. (62886135)
property wrappers now work as expected when contained inside an
, causing the system to emit the
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/combine/observableobject/objectwillchange-2oa5v
publisher. (65562845)
instances that the system initializes with a
object now correctly track updates to the
object from background threads, and no longer issue a “not allowed” console warning. (69999449)
Using
without specifying an anchor now scrolls the
the minimum amount to make it visible. (70184639)
Don’t use the iOS
information property list key to declare the minimum release of macOS in which your app runs. Use
Future releases of macOS ignore the
key in Mac apps, including apps built with Mac Catalyst.
Future releases of macOS use the
key in iOS apps built with Xcode 12.5 or later. If an iOS app doesn’t include an
key, future releases of macOS compare the app’s
with the version of its Mac Catalyst runtime to determine compatibility.

abstract.text: The minimum version of the operating system required for the app to run in macOS.
The minimum version of the operating system required for the app to run in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, and watchOS.
A type of object with a publisher that emits before the object has changed.
A type that publishes a property marked with an attribute.
A property wrapper type that reflects a value from `UserDefaults` and invalidates a view on a change in value in that user default.
A type that applies standard interaction behavior and a custom appearance to all buttons within a view hierarchy.
Placement for commands that manipulate the toolbar.
Command menus are stand-alone, top-level containers for controls that perform related, app-specific commands.
A scene that enables support for opening, creating, and saving documents.
A property wrapper that reads a value from a view’s environment.
The size to apply to controls within a view.
A convenience property wrapper for observing and automatically unwrapping state bindings from the focused view or one of its ancestors.
A property wrapper for observing values from the focused view or one of its ancestors.
A stylized view, with an optional label, that visually collects a logical grouping of content.
A standard label for user interface items, consisting of an icon with a title.
A container that presents rows of data arranged in a single column, optionally providing the ability to select one or more members.
A wrapper that you use to integrate an AppKit view into your SwiftUI view hierarchy.
A structure that computes views and disclosure groups on demand from an underlying collection of tree-structured, identified data.
A view that shows the progress toward completion of a task.
Scans all scroll views contained by the proxy for the first with a child view with identifier `id`, and then scrolls to that view.
A property wrapper type that can read and write a value managed by SwiftUI.
A label style that shows both the title and icon of the label using a system-standard layout.
The appearance and behavior of a toggle.
A model that represents an item which can be placed in the toolbar or navigation bar.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides modifiers that you use to configure views.
Positions this view within an invisible frame with the specified size.
A control for incrementing or decrementing a value.
Update your apps to use new features, and test your apps against API changes.
An object that conveys ongoing progress to the user for a specified task.
Considerations for running iPhone and iPad apps on Macs with Apple silicon.
